title: Art & Outdoors
text:
I’ve played the viola for 10 years and music has contributed to so many of my most favorite experiences and memories. Through various fundraiser performances, seasonal concerts, weddings, and tours, I’ve met incredible people and life-long friends.












Santa Monica High School 2022 Symphony Orchestra tour to NYC, performing at Carnegie Hall.


  

Above is a practice clip of Festive Overture, Op. 96 by Dmitri Shostakovich. To the right, find a video of where this practiced passage is featured in the performance.



  

Antonín Dvořák  Serenade in E major, Op. 22, III. Scherzo: Vivace  Mar. 24, 2022 | Barnum Hall | Santa Monica, CA  Click Festive Overture to watch the entire performance.



2022 All-State High School Symphony Orchestra


  



Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov  Scheherazade, Op. 35, IV. Allegro Molto  Feb. 19, 2022 | Saroyan Theater | Fresno, CA  Click Scheherazade 2022 to watch our performance.  Recipient of Tuition Scholarship to Sequoia Chamber Music Festival Summer 2022






I’ve recorded myself making music since I was 9-years old. Through apps like Voice Memos, SoundTrap, and GarageBand, I learned to layer multiple parts to create my own ensemble inside my room. Below are two of my first projects from high school.


  

Untitled, 2021  I really liked the opening theme to “Pressure” by Billy Joel and wondered what it would sound like if it were remixed. In this project, I was aiming for an ominous and dark tone, and I had a lot of fun layering parts!



  

Improvised Duet, 2021  Here, I chose the key of D minor and improvised a duet that I played on my viola. Each part was recorded in one take. I love how this piece captures a sense of reflection and optimism towards the end.









Today, you’ll find me jamming with my friends Kai Mawhinney on keys and Emmett Levine on voice and guitar. We’ve performed on the Claremont College student radio, KSPC, several times and are incredibly thankful to them for hosting us. Click the icon to the right to learn more about KSPC.

title: Art & Outdoors
text:
Outdoors

Ultimate Frisbee



The Claremont Braineaters are a group of frisbee enthusiasts from all over the Claremont Colleges. We are an inclusive, gender expansive team and hold trainings three times a week for 2-hours to practice gameplay, strategy, and have a good time. Last season, we represented the South West region at the Men’s Division-III Nationals 2024 in Milwaukee, earning the Team Spirit Award for outstanding knownledge of the game and sportsmanship. I’ve made countless memories with the team both on and off field, and I’m excited to see where we go this season.










Team photo of the Braineaters at USA Ultimate Division-III Mens Nationals 2024.

title: Art & Outdoors
text:
Additional Interests & Hobbies
In addition to music and frisbee, I also enjoy sketching, running, and woodworking. This winter break, I’m working on running 100 miles!







Untitled, 2023  Pencil on paper








Winter Break Run, 2024 








Woodworking Gifts, 2024

title: Engineering Class Projects
text: During the semester, I love working on hands-on projects to develop new and useful skills to broaden my problem solving toolbox. I believe projects and experiments are the best way to learn for yourself what works and what doesn’t, and adjust as needed to keep moving foward. My projects bring me great satisfaction and I love putting in the time and effort to bringing my ideas to life. If they work, wonderful! And if they don’t turn out as expected, I take what I learn and quickly and efficiently tweak my methods until I reach my desired outcome. Check out some of the projects I’ve worked on at Mudd so far!

title: Engineering Class Projects
text:
E4: Design & Manufacturing

Machinist Hammer







Over the course of 6-weeks, I gained proficiency in basic machining techniques, joined the long hammer-building history of Harvey Mudd College engineers, and discovered a deeper appreciation for machining that led me to working as a shop proctor at the Harvey Mudd Machine Shop. The student Machine Shop is a fundamental resource to many student projects and experiences across the Claremont Colleges.







Show More






What?







All Harvey Mudd students in E4 manufacture identical machinist hammers by following specific process routers and tolerances listed in tech drawings.
Crafted a machinist hammer from clear oak, AISI 1015 steel, AISI 4340 steel, and nylon.







How?







Machined head stock to length and specification using lathe and milling operations.
Heat treated hardface and determined HRC Hardness.
Lasercut hammer stand and shaped handle using the bandsaw and spindle sander.







Results







Created a functional hammer with heat treated hard face, well fastened soft face, and smooth handle finish.
Hammer is durable and approved as high quality of manufacturing.
Inspired to become a machine shop proctor and train new users.












Optimization of Neuroimaging Apparatus







Dr. Burns at Pomona College uses functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS) to monitor brain activity by measuring how infrared light (IR) interacts with oxygenated hemoglobin (HbO) in the brain. A significant challenge arises when using fNIRS with individuals who have thick or darker hair, as the hair can block the IR light from properly reaching the scalp. With my team—Annette Chang, Brock Bownds, and Gabrielle Reynolds, we sought to develop methods to effectively direct IR light from fNIRS devices to the scalp.







Show More






What?







Developed and selected three design alternatives:


Fiber Optic Attachment with Custom Spring Cap threads IR light through thick hair to the scalp.
Hair Moving Pick moves hair away from covering the scalp.
Wider Mounting Base enables more pressure between the scalp and optodes.







How?







Machined prototypes to verify proof of concept and refined iterations based on client input and professor feedback.
Developed comprehen- sive process routers for all prototype designs and documented findings into reports to be shared with the team and the client.
Fostered a welcoming and collaborative environment for all team members.







Results







Improved signal clarity of fNIR device for users with dense hair types (3C, 4A), improving readings from critical to acceptable.
Gained experience arranging and executing client meetings to determine project objectives, constraint, functions, and means.
Applied principles of engineering design and team dynamics to a real-world project.

title: Engineering Class Projects
text:
E79: Engineering Systems

Underwater Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV)







I worked with my lab partner, Brock Bownds, to build an underwater remotely operated vehicle (ROV) to gather depth and temperature data of designated 3D location in Phake Lake neighboring the Harvey Mudd College campus.







Show More






What?







Created an ROV with an umbillical cord to measure depth and temperature data at Phake Lake located across Foothill Blvd.
The ROV is fully water- proof and its motor is controlled using a P control system that we modeled with block diagrams.







How?







Modeled and simulated vertical motion of the ROV using LabView and generated Bode Plots to characterize second order transient response.
Built, tested, and manufactured a circuit that can convert tempertures to voltages using a 10kΩ thermistor.







Results







Gained hands-on skills breadboarding circuits and soldering compo- nents onto PCBs to create functional sensors.
Proficiency with oscilloscope equipment.
Deployment spot stats : Depth (m): [0, 1.32],  Temp (ºC): [-3.80, 19.18].

title: Engineering Class Projects
text:
E85: Digital Electronics & Computer Architecture (RISC-V)

2D-Digital Level







Combining an accelerometer and a 7x7 LED array with technical skills in soldering, breadboaring, and C Code, I created a 2D-digital level to determine whether my dorm desk was level. For this project, I used a SparkFun RED-V ThingPlus board.  Click Digital Demo to view a video demo of the level on my desk.







Show More






What?







The LED matrix displays a red “bubble” indicating the orientation of the accelerometer in the x and y axes.
When the accelerometer is level, the bubble lies at the center of the 7x7 LED matrix display.
The bubble stops at the edge of the matrix if the tilt of the breadboard is too large.







How?







Interpreted LED data sheet to determine current limiting resistor values as well as pinout configuration.
Soldered accelerometer and created a circuit schematic to streamline C Code.
Calibrated accelerometer by tilting in 5º intevals along axes and recording output readings.







Results







Click Digital Demo to view a video demo of the level on my desk.
Wrote embedded software using C Code to control external peripherals.
Designed an accurate and sensitive 2D-digital level.
Determined that my dorm desk is level!












32-Bit Multicycle Processor (RISC-V)







My culminating project for E85 was to build, simulate, and debug a multicycle RISC-V processor in SystemVerilog. This project built upon the ALU Decoder and Single-cycle processor we designed in previous labs.  To view a larger version of the images for this project as well as my code, click Multicycle Code.







Show More






What?







Created a 32-bit multicycle computer processor that can compute arithmetic operations, manage memory, and execute instructions in real-time.
Click Multicycle Code to view my code starting on page 2.







How?







Wrote a datapath in SystemVerilog to connect controller, memory, and register file components.
Systematically debugged my code by comparing assembly and machine language test benches against waveforms, identifying error origins.
Consulted Quartus RLT schematic to ensure accurate I/O ports.







Results







32-Bit RISC-V Multicycle processor matched waveform expectations, indicating that the corret values where written to the correct address.
Adapted Single-cycle processor building blocks such as muxes, registers, and adders for Multicycle processor use.
Deep understanding of function instantiation and module hierarchy for SystemVerilog.

title: D. Sebastian Heredia
text:
Hello! My name is Sebastian (He/Him) and I’m a Sophomore Engineering major at Harvey Mudd College in Claremont, CA. I am passionate about electronics and manufacturing, and hope to leverage these fields to make a positive impact on the world. To make my goals a reality, I seek hands-on, professional experience in technical engineering projects.
As an engineer, machinist, and tutor I’ve gained technical skills in CAD and computer programming, design and manufacturing, and teaching that I’m excited to apply to helping communities all over. I love challenging myself to not only learn, but master new skills. I hope to combine skills in new and unique ways to make novel creations that help people. Check out my resume and additional links below!
